column8: Title
column9: Description
column10: Bill summary (plain-language)

column8: No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act of 2017
column9: This legislation would make harmful, discriminatory abortion coverage restrictions permanent and interfere with private health insurance coverage for abortion. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Restricting Abortion Coverage

column8: A joint resolution disapproving the rule submitted by the Department of Defense, the General Services Administration, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration relating to the Federal Acquisition Regulation.
column9: This legislation would overturn the regulations implementing the 2014 Fair Pay and Safe Workplaces executive order, which require federal agencies to contract only with companies that comply with workplace safety laws, sexual harassment laws, anti-discrimination laws, and minimum wage and overtime laws. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Overturning Fair Pay and Safe Workplaces

column8: A joint resolution disapproving the rule submitted by the Social Security Administration relating to Implementation of the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007.
column9: This legislation would overturn a federal rule to add the names of Social Security disability benefit recipients to the national background check system used during gun purchases. In contrast to well-crafted measures that respect civil liberties while reducing gun violence, the rule in question raises due process concerns and reinforces the harmful and unsupported stereotype that people with mental disabilities, a vast and diverse group of citizens, are violent. (ACLU Position: Supported)
column10: Overturning Rule that Requires Disclosure of Disabilities During Gun Purchases

column8: A joint resolution disapproving the rule submitted by the Department of Education relating to accountability and State plans under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
column9: This legislation would, in effect, overturn critical protections for historically marginalized students, including students of color, students with disabilities, and students who are English learners, immigrants, girls, Native American, LGBTQ, or low-income students. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Overturning Protection for Historically Marginalized Students

column8: A joint resolution disapproving the rule submitted by Secretary of Health and Human Services relating to compliance with title X requirements by project recipients in selecting subrecipients.
column9: This legislation would overturn a federal rule that reinforces protections against ideologically driven attempts to exclude qualified reproductive health care providers from participating in the Title X family planning program. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Overturn the Protection Against Ideologically Driven Attempts to Exclude Health Care providers from Title X Family Planning

column8: A joint resolution disapproving the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to "Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services."
column9: This legislation would overturn federal privacy protection rules that require broadband internet service providers to get customers’ consent before sharing their sensitive data with third parties. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Overturn Privacy Protection Rules in Internet Service Providers

column8: Working Families Flexibility Act of 2017
column9: This legislation claims to help employees balance work and family obligations, but instead it risks undermining meaningful access to paid leave and forces people to choose between compensation for the extra time they worked and scheduling flexibility to meet their families’ needs. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Forces People to Choose Between Work and Family

column8: American Health Care Act of 2017
column9: This legislation would repeal key provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), block patients from accessing care at Planned Parenthood, place new restrictions on abortion coverage, and radically alter Medicaid’s funding and structure in such a way as to cause great harm to people with disabilities. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Repeals Key Provisions of the Affordable Care Act

column8: Thin Blue Line Act
column9: This legislation would subject a person to the death penalty for killing or targeting law enforcement. It is unnecessary and duplicative of existing law, counterproductive to improving law enforcement and community relations, and unlikely to prevent future violence against police. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Expands the Death Penalty

column8: Probation Officer Protection Act of 2017
column9: This legislation would give federal probation officers the authority to arrest people who are not on probation without a warrant, despite the lack of evidence that current arrest authority is insufficient. H.R. 1039 would also create safety concerns for both probation officers and the community and risks violating people's Fourth Amendment rights. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Expands Federal Probation Officers’ Authority to Arrest without a Warrant

column8: No Sanctuary for Criminals Act
column9: This legislation would force state and local law enforcement agencies to violate the Fourth Amendment by requiring them to imprison people without due process or probable cause at the request of federal immigration agents. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Force Law Enforcement Agencies to Violate the Fourth Amendment

column8: Kate's Law
column9: This legislation would increase already strict penalties for undocumented immigrants who reenter the United States, while ignoring any humanitarian considerations. The bill also limits immigrants’ ability to challenge prior removal orders in court regardless of whether they were lawfully obtained, in violation of due process. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Impose Draconian Penalties on Undocumented Immigrants and Remove Certain Due Process Protections in Immigration Court

column8: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018 - Rep. Hartzler Amendment #315
column9: In a discriminatory, unconstitutional attack on transgender service members and their families, this amendmentwould bar transgender members of the Armed Forces and military dependents from receiving appropriate and medically necessary health care. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Bars Transgender Service Members and Military Dependents From Receiving Medically Necessary Care

column8: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018 - Rep. Franks' Amendment #68
column9: This legislation would violate the Constitution by requiringthe federal government, in violation of the Constitution, to single out Muslims and Islam under the cover of conducting “strategic assessments” of religious doctrine, singling out Muslims and Islam and casting suspicion on an entire religion, chilling freedoms of speech, association, and religion. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Requires the Federal Government to Single out Muslims and Islam for “Strategic Assessments”

column8: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3354) making appropriations for the Department of the Interior, environment, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2018, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of motions to suspend the rules; and waiving a requirement of clause 6(a) of rule XIII with respect to consideration of certain resolutions reported from the Committee on Rules.
column9: The House voted on whether to allow a vote on the Dream Act in a procedural move, where a vote 'yes' meant voting to reject the Dream Act, and a vote 'no' meant voting to support the Dream Act. The Dream Act would grant undocumented immigrant youth who came to the U.S. as children access to work permits, protect them from deportation, and provide them with a pathway to citizenship. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Rejecting the Dream Act

column8: Make America Secure and Prosperous Appropriations Act, 2018 - Reps. DeLauro, Frankel, Scott Amendment #113
column9: This legislation would preserve funding for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s revised Employer Information Report, a critical equal pay initiative. (ACLU Position: Supported)
column10: Preserve Funding for An Equal Pay Initiative

column8: Make America Secure and Prosperous Appropriations Act, 2018 - Reps. Ellison, Grijalva, Pocan Amendment #186
column9: This legislation would ensure that the federal government does not contract with entities that willfully and repeatedly violate the Fair Labor Standards Act. (ACLU Position: Supported)
column10: Ensures Federal Government Does Not Contract Violators of the Fair Labor Standards Act

column8: Criminal Alien Gang Removal Act
column9: This sweeping anti-immigrant legislation would give the federal government massive discretion to deport people based on an unacceptably low standard of what constitutes gang involvement, expand immigration authorities' powers to conduct dragnet sweeps of communities of color, and bar humanitarian relief for individuals in violation of international treaties. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Grant the Federal Government Sweeping Discretion to Profile, Arrest and Deport Immigrants on Unsubstantiated Allegations of “Gang Involvement”

column8: Make America Secure and Prosperous Appropriations Act, 2018 - Rep. Palmer Amendment #192
column9: This legislation would block Washington, D.C. from carrying out the Reproductive Health Non-Discrimination Act (RHNDA), a local law protecting employees from discrimination in the workplace based on their personal reproductive health care decisions. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Enabling Discrimination Based on Reproductive Health Care Decisions

column8: Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act
column9: This bill is an extreme and unconstitutional nationwide pre-viability ban on abortion that interferes with a woman's most personal medical decisions and violates fundamental constitutional principles. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Banning Abortion at 20 Weeks Nationwide

column6: Amash of Michigan Substitute Amendment No. 1
column8: FISA Amendments Reauthorization Act - Substitute Amendment, the USA RIGHTS Act
column9: This legislation, offered as a substitute amendment to S. 139, would reform Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) to protect Americans' civil liberties while closing illegal surveillance loopholes and enabling the government to continue pursuing national security leads. (ACLU Position: Supported)
column10: Protecting Americans from Illegal Government Surveillance

column8: FISA Amendments Reauthorization Act - Substitute Amendment, the USA RIGHTS Act
column9: This legislation would fail to meaningfully reform Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) to protect Americans from illegal government spying and make current law more vulnerable to government abuses. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Failure to Protect Americans from Illegal Government Surveillance

column8: Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act
column9: This legislation would interfere with the patient-provider relationship, target providers, and mislead the public about safe, legal abortion. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Targeting Abortion Providers and Misinforming the Public

column8: ADA Education and Reform Act of 2017
column9: This legislation would fundamentally alter and undermine the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by creating more obstacles for people with disabilities before they can enforce their rights and shifting the burden away from businesses to comply with civil rights law to the person denied access. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Changing the ADA to Put More Burden on People with Disabilities

column8:
Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act of 2017
 (FOSTA)
column9: This legislation poses a risk to freedom of speech on the Internet as we have come to know it, while failing to successfully reconcile the goal to stop the use of the internet for sex trafficking and the goal to ensure a thriving internet by retaining certain liability protections for online platform providers. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Attempt to Stop Online Sex Trafficking by Limiting Free Speech and Endangering Sex Workers

column4: On Motion to Concur in the Senate Amendment with an Amendment
column8: Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018
column9: In this vote to pass a large government spending bill, the ACLU opposed the legislation because of the version of the "Clarifying Lawful Overseas Use of Data Act (CLOUD Act)" contained within. The CLOUD Act jeopardizes Americans’ privacy, threatens human rights, and grants the executive branch broad discretion with inadequate checks to prevent abuse. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Funding Data Collection Via the CLOUD Act

column8: Citizens' Right to Know Act of 2018
column9: This legislation would establish the collection and public reporting of personally identifiable information of people participating in pretrial services programs—individuals who have not been convicted of a crime given their pretrial status. In addition to raising privacy concerns, the bill would undermine efforts to reform the money bail system. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Requires Reporting of Personal Information of Pretrial Program Participants

column8: Protect and Serve Act
column9: This legislation would create a new crime for offenses that target law enforcement officers. The bill is unnecessary because police already have substantial protections under federal and state law. Moreover, it is divisive because it advances a false, dangerous narrative that there is a "war on police" - a narrative that appears to be a political response to the growing national movement for police accountability. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Gives Law Enforcement Protected Class Status and Advances “Blue Lives Matter” Narrative

column4: On Motion to Suspend the Rules and Pass, as Amended
column8: The First Step Act
column9: This legislation, would attempt to establish reforms to the criminal justice system for those currently incarcerated. However, the bill would not achieve meaningful reform to the federal system because it does not reforms to sentencing laws such as reducing mandatory minimum sentences, restoring judicial discretion, and mitigating disparate impacts on communities of color. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Minimal changes to the federal prison system

column8: Community Safety and Security Act of 2018
column9:
This legislation would expand the definition of "crime of violence" to include offenses that have no element of violence. The phrase "crime of violence" is referenced throughout U.S. law in various contexts, including immigration law. The expanded definition would further fuel mass incarceration, allowing for severe, costly, and punitive sentences to apply to low-level crimes, and could prevent people accused of misdemeanors from being released pre-trial. Importantly, it would also lead to generally non-violent offenses triggering nobond
detention and deportation for immigrants. (ACLU Position: Opposed)

column8: Michael Davis, Jr. and Danny Oliver in Honor of State and Local Law Enforcement Act (SAFE Act)
column9: This legislation, considered by the House Judiciary Committee, would criminalize undocumented immigrants, eliminate due process protections, and undermine the federal government’s supremacy in regards to immigration enforcement. The bill would also force states and localities to divert resources toward immigration enforcement, lead to racial profiling, and promote unfair treatment of immigrants and citizens. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Criminalize Immigrants, Remove Due Process Protections, and Give State and Local Jurisdictions Unfettered Immigration Enforcement Power

column8: United States Citizenship and Immigration Services Authorization Act
column9: Considered in the House Judiciary Committee, this legislation to reauthorize U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) contains problematic provisions, including the creation of new directorate positions without strong oversight and the permanent authorization of the ineffective and error-prone E-Verify system for checking work authorization. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Expansion of USCIS With Serious Flaws

column8: Immigration and Customs Enforcement Authorization Act of 2017
column9: This legislation, considered by the House Judiciary Committee, would authorize Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) as the principal Department of Homeland Security agency charged with enforcing federal immigration laws and do so in a manner fraught with constitutional problems, including expanding ICE's warrantless authority and arming ICE officers with combat weapons. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Authorization of ICE as Principal Immigration Enforcement Agency

column8: Legal Workforce Act
column9: This bill would force all employers to use the error-prone E-Verify program for checking work authorization, which would threaten privacy, harm many authorized workers due to the error rate, and impose unacceptable burdens on America’s workers and businesses. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Violation of Workers’ Privacy

column8: USA Liberty Act - Rep. Poe Amendment
column9: This amendment offered in the House Judiciary Committee would help close the "backdoor search loophole" for a key surveillance provision of the FISA Amendments Act, which allows the U.S. government to collect foreign intelligence information but sweeps in communications by U.S. persons. The loophole allows the government to search massive databases without a warrant for information about U.S. persons and persons inside the U.S. (ACLU Position: Supported)
column10: Authorizing Certain Government Warrantless Searches

column4: On Motion to Favorably Report H.R. 4478, as amended
column8: FISA Amendments Reauthorization Act of 2017
column9: This legislation, considered in the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence,fails to meaningfully address the litany of surveillance abuses that have occurred under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, while at the same risking the codification of current illegal practices and expansion of surveillance under Section 702. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Excusing and Expanding Surveillance Abuses

column8: Citizens' Right to Know Act of 2018
column9: This legislation, considered in the House Judiciary Committee, would establish the collection and public reporting of personally identifiable information of people participating in pretrial services programs—individuals who have not been convicted of a crime given their pretrial status. In addition to raising privacy concerns, the bill would undermine efforts to reform the money bail system. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Privacy Violation of People Participating in Pretrial Programs

column8: Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2019
column9: This legislation, considered as an amendment in the House Appropriations Committee, would harm children in the child welfare system and authorize taxpayer-funded discrimination. In violation of state and federal nondiscrimination policies, the amendment would allow child welfare providers receiving taxpayer dollars to decide which families and children to serve, and would place the religious and moral beliefs of certain child welfare service providers above the best interests of children who are in state care because of abuse and neglect at home. It would empower providers to use a religious litmus test to turn away prospective parents simply because of who they are, something that would significantly impact LGBTQ people and non-Christians. The amendment would affect a wide variety of child welfare services, including family preservation services; foster care, counseling and other services for children; and adoption services. (ACLU Position: Opposed)
column10: Enabling Taxpayer-Funded Discrimination in the Child Welfare System
